summary: This document is a chain of emails from November 10, 2020, between U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (USANYS) personnel and a law firm. It concerns the forwarding of a letter from the Marsh Law Firm regarding a potential victim of Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell. The emails discuss the need to verify the victim's status, reference prior aggressive litigation by the law firm, and inquire about an HSI agent checking images with NCMEC.

persons.name: Jennifer Freeman
persons.context: Sends the initial email with an annexed letter concerning a potential Epstein/Maxwell victim to Audrey Strauss.

persons.name: Audrey Strauss
persons.role: U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York
persons.context: Primary recipient of the initial email from Jennifer Freeman; the letter is forwarded to her regarding a potential victim.

persons.name: Joyanna Silberg
persons.context: Copied on the initial email from Jennifer Freeman to Audrey Strauss.

connections.description: Jennifer Freeman, an attorney, sends a confidential letter regarding a potential victim to U.S. Attorney Audrey Strauss.

events.title: Email Chain Regarding Potential Victim Letter
events.description: A chain of emails is exchanged within the U.S. Attorney's Office (SDNY) regarding a letter from the Marsh Law Firm about a potential victim of Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell.

keyFacts: The Marsh Law Firm sent a letter to the U.S. Attorney's Office (SDNY) concerning a potential victim of Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell.
The email chain indicates the Marsh Law Firm was known for being 'very aggressive in representing victims of child pornography' and that prior litigation was involved.
An inquiry is made within the emails about whether an HSI agent has run images through NCMEC to identify them and the series they belong to.
The correspondence highlights internal DOJ procedures for handling communications about potential victims in charged cases.
